report_title: Industry Report on Herbal Tea Production
executive_summary: Herbal tea producers have prospered over some of the five years to 2024 because of an expansion in health consciousness and tea consumption among consumers. Consistent demand from the aging population is attributable to intense marketing by herbal tea producers to boost awareness about the health benefits of herbal teas. Price-premium teas with organic blends have become popular amid expanded discretionary income levels. However, competition from low-cost imports has offset most domestic tea demand expansion amid the strengthening US dollar. IBISWorld estimates that herbal tea revenue will expand at a CAGR of an estimated 0.2% to $470.0 million through the end of 2024, including an estimated 0.6% increase in 2024 alone. COVID-19 has been a contributing factor to this low annualized growth in revenue across the industry. Meanwhile, profit will inch down to represent approximately 8.7% of revenue in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The United States doesn't have the proper tea-growing climate, forcing domestic tea producers to import leaves and making input prices susceptible to political conflicts and environmental condition changes. An appreciating US dollar boosts the price of domestic tea abroad and makes the cost of imported tea sink, pushing consumers away from domestically produced tea and lowering exports. This can harm domestic tea producers who lose the international market share, leading to potential job losses in the sector.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Expanded Demand for Alternative Remedies Has Boosted Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The aging demographic trend of the US population has boosted the number of people at risk for various ailments, like diabetes, encouraging consumers to purchase herbal teas frequently cited as potential aids for numerous health conditions. Consumers have recently been motivated to seek herbal tea remedies because of the expanding cost of conventional healthcare and pharmaceuticals. Also, easy access to online information about the potential benefits of herbal tea remedies has significantly contributed to this trend.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Surging Health Awareness Supports Herbal Tea Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Herbal teas have surged in popularity as more baby boomers opt for caffeine-free teas. The undesirable effects of caffeine-insomnia connections have made noncaffeinated teas favorable for the aging population. Expanding herbal tea consumption fits into a nationwide trend of consumers seeking out foods and beverages that are purported to have healthful and anti-aging effects.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Expanded Marketing Efforts and Product Variety Has Aided Herbal Tea Performance
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Aggressive media promotion from brands like Lipton and Celestial Seasonings has supported belief in the health benefits of tea consumption. Such aggressive media promotions have greatly amplified public awareness and acceptance of tea as a healthy beverage choice, boosting its popularity. Herbal tea companies are also expanding their range of flavors, ensuring a taste for nearly everyone. They are investing in media exposure to reach a wider consumer base and promote diverse options for health and enjoyment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Macroeconomic Trends Are Set to Improve
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the coming years, the US dollar will devaluate, making domestically produced tea more affordable abroad and boosting demand. On the other hand, imports sold in the United States will strengthen in price, benefiting domestic producers. When inflation falls, consumers often experience an enhancement in their purchasing power. This improvement means they can afford to buy more than just essential items, creating an opportunity for industries that sell non-necessity products. Among these non-essential products, items like tea will likely see a surge in sales as consumers have more disposable income.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Changes in Consumer Behavior Will Encourage Producers to Invest More in R&D
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As consumers become more acquainted with different tea varieties, their palate expands and evolves. This growth and familiarity will lead them to expect and demand new innovative flavors and unique combinations in herbal teas. The production of these new teas necessitates a specialized team of food scientists for product improvement and innovation. This boosting wage expenses, limiting overall profit. Incorporating these specialists creates ongoing additional costs, which can impact financial performance.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: An Expanding Consumer Base Will Drive Demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The large baby boomer demographic significantly consumes herbal tea, with swelling demand predicted because of their aging. This trend is propelled by their strengthening health consciousness and preference for natural wellness products. Longevity is projected to accelerate amid continuously improving healthcare technologies, expanding the number of people with chronic diseases that become more common in old age. As more consumers expand their herbal tea consumption because of its purported health benefits, demand will be resilient despite high competition from other alternative remedies.

Changes in dietary trends towards healthier options will benefit tea producers significantly. Many consumers now seek to incorporate products that are low in fat and sugar into their diets, making tea an attractive choice.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry specialize in blending and packaging plant infusions, creating an array of herbal teas. These teas can be derived from any leaf, root, fruit or flower that comes from plants other than the traditional tea plant. This diverse industry harnesses various botanicals' natural benefits and flavors, providing consumers with a range of healthy and delicious beverage choices.
key_trends: Expansively health-conscious consumers support herbal tea sales.
Many people want to change their consumption of sugary drinks to healthier alternatives like tea.

A strong US dollar harms domestic manufacturers as herbal tea produced abroad is comparatively more affordable. This lowers demand for domestic tea abroad and expands sales of imported tea domestically.

Sales of fair-trade products are swelling in popularity worldwide, with consumers becoming expansively interested in the ethical consumerism movement. These consumers often pay premium prices to ensure their tea is ethically sourced and produced.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Direct sales of herbal tea are typically made over the Internet to various customers, usually small to medium-size organizations that have developed relationships with niche or specialty producers. This segment also includes direct sales to specialty retail tearooms since some bigger enterprises can purchase bulk quantities directly from manufacturers, providing them with cost benefits.

market_segmentation.segment: Retail Trade and Food Service Industry
market_segmentation.segment_description: Food service companies, supermarket and grocery chains, and health, drug and convenience stores are included in this segment. Given the importance of this channel, manufacturers must form strong relationships with retailers that have been steadily expanding its market share.

Motels, hotels, airlines, restaurants, fast-food chains and convention centers also purchase large quantities of herbal tea products for use in their kitchens and functions, sometimes purchased directly from manufacturers at reduced costs.

products_and_services.product_description: Chamomile tea is produced from a flowering plant that resembles a daisy. The tea is used for various medicinal purposes, most commonly to help with relaxation and sleep disorders.

Peppermint, spearmint and other mint teas have a high concentration of menthol essential oil, thus making it a popular drink for anti-inflammatory effects. As a result, they are a popular choice for individuals seeking natural remedies for inflammation and associated ailments. Known for its strong aroma and refreshing taste, mint possesses potent antibacterial and antiviral properties, making it a popular drink for alleviating symptoms and aiding recovery from colds and other respiratory issues.

Other herbal teas collectively comprise more than half of herbal tea revenue, with some of the most popular types of herbal teas being senna, ginger, cinnamon, ginseng, artichoke, cinnamon, licorice root, St. John's wort, sage and echinacea, as well as fruit-infused options. Ginger teas are helpful for digestion, while St. John's wort can be helpful for mild forms of depression and echinacea and licorice root teas are often used for promoting respiratory health.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Herbal teas are perceived as a healthy alternative to sugary drinks, driving demand from health-conscious consumers.
The growing popularity of natural and organic products boosts demand for herbal teas made from organic plants and natural sweeteners.
Higher disposable income allows consumers to purchase premium herbal tea products, benefiting producers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports Satisfy a Chunk of Domestic Demand
international_trade_points.trade_description: South Korea's high-quality standards extend to its herbal tea production, known for its natural ingredients and medicinal properties, raising the bar for imported herbal teas. Relatively lower labor costs overseas, like in China, and local harvesting of tea leaves lower production costs, pushing down prices and strengthening demand. An appreciating US dollar results in higher prices of domestically produced herbal tea. This, in turn, pushes consumers to seek cheaper alternatives, driving demand for foreign-produced herbal tea. This scenario benefits international tea exporters while affecting local producers.

Tariffs on tea from China, once the largest tea importer, expanded during the trade war, driving up the price of imported tea. The pandemic negatively impacted imports' share of herbal tea revenue in 2020, as China went through a major lockdown to prevent the spread of COVID-19, pressuring production and sales.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports Benefit from the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA)
international_trade_points.trade_description: Trade agreements between the United States, Mexico and Canada minimize trade barriers and tariffs, supporting the expansion of herbal tea producers. These agreements allow herbal tea producers to access wider markets, expand export opportunities and drive industry growth by facilitating the trade of unique tea blends across North America. Because of their proximity and lower trade barriers, Mexico and Canada are major export destinations for herbal tea. In these countries, demand for such teas, which are embraced for their health benefits, escalates these trade ties.

international_trade_points.trade_title: An Appreciating US Dollar Harms Export Revenue
international_trade_points.trade_description: The pandemic resulted in many unstable governments, pushing up the value of the US dollar compared with other currencies. This surge in the US dollar positively impacted importers of herbal tea, making foreign-sourced ingredients more affordable. A strong US dollar greatly influences the price of domestically produced herbal tea, making it more expensive. This negatively impacts herbal tea exporters as their products become less competitive globally.

business_locations.location_description: The region has easy access to population-dense regions, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Seattle, lowering transportation costs. California is also known for having a health-conscious culture, pushing up demand for tea. Commercial farms in the West region are a prominent source of herbal inputs for herbal tea producers. These farms cultivate a wide variety of herbs including chamomile, lavender and mint.

Many major ports are based in the Southeast, resulting in lower transportation costs and easy input access. The Southeast is a sugar-producing region and prominent fruit producer, benefiting producers in the area by pushing down input transportation costs. Minimum wage requirements are lower in the Southeast than in other regions, which results in dipping operating expenses, effectively attracting businesses seeking to minimize labor costs.

business_locations.location: Great Lakes, Mid-Atlantic and Other Regions
business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region is home to Illinois, the most prominent state in the region, given its large consumer market in Chicago. This becomes alluring for herbal tea producers, who can take advantage of the large consumer base, appealing to the region's varied tastes and health consciousnesses. The Mid-Atlantic has access to major ports and is another prominent center of industry activity, home to some of the country's biggest and most affluent cities, like New York City and Philadelphia. Although New England and the Rocky Mountains make up a small share of herbal tea revenue, prominent producer Bigelow Tea Company is headquartered in Connecticut and Celestial Seasonings is based in Colorado.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) sets production and labeling standards. It evaluates and controls manufacturer information required about ingredients, serving size and claims regarding nutritional content for herbal tea producers. Producers must register their facilities with the FDA and comply with the labeling standards. Herbal tea manufacturers must also comply with the FDA's Good Manufacturing Practices (GMPs), which monitor the manufacturing process of herbal teas, including herb identification and purity.

The Commission diligently oversees advertising claims to maintain integrity and consumer trust in the market. All claims must adhere to the truth-in-advertising standard. This implies that advertisements should be honest and non-deceptive and backed up with solid evidence. Any claim about a product or service must be adequately substantiated, meaning they must provide the necessary proof to support their assertions.

regulations_points.regulation_title: STATE OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY ADMINISTRATIONS
regulations_points.regulation_description: Like other businesses, herbal tea producers must adhere to certain regulatory standards. This includes compliance with occupational health and safety laws designed to protect workers from potential hazards in the workplace. They must also respect labor laws concerning overtime pay and certain employment conditions like minimum wage, working hours and mandatory breaks. Any violation of these laws can lead to legal consequences for the company.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) continues to provide updated and ongoing guidelines in response to public health situations for businesses, including those in the herbal tea industry, ensuring these guidelines remain dynamic and adaptable. Amid the pandemic, employees presenting any health symptoms had to be immediately segregated from their work environment. Also, employees who tested positive for COVID-19 were required to notify their colleagues about potential exposure risk.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Herbal tea producers are leaning toward automation to expand efficiency and reduce operating costs. These trends are starting to reverse as more producers invest in research and development and the industry expansively relies on human capital.

basis_points.basis_title: Primary competitive factors within the industry
basis_points.basis_description: The primary competitive factors within the industry are price, brand loyalty, quality, relationships with supplier networks and product differentiation.

Herbal tea producers endure external competition from black, green and white teas. These producers also suffer external competition from juice producers that manufacture ready-to-drink (RTD) and blended iced tea varieties and other relaxation drinks may also threaten demand.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Major herbal tea producers benefit from prominent brand loyalty, as consumers relate large brands with good quality standards. Smaller producers don't have the same brand recognition, resulting in lower sales across the mainstream market.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Consumer Preferences Open Opportunities in Niche Markets
concentration_points.concentration_description: Smaller producers have been able to serve various niche markets, particularly consumers interested in gourmet or specialty teas, thereby giving them a unique competitive edge in the industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases constitute the most significant portion of revenue, as most producers import tea production inputs, including herbs like ginger, spearmint, cinnamon and licorice root, flowers, fruits, roots and seeds. Herbal tea manufacturers purchase packaging materials like plastic, cardboard, paper or silk. Heavy investment is also made in advanced machinery for efficient production. The input supply chain is highly globalized, making prices susceptible to political conflicts, global emergencies and environmental factors. Exchange rate fluctuations, trade policies, local laws, transport disruptions and manufacturing issues can also influence it. Herbal tea producers also purchase a wide range of products for production and packaging, including tea leaves, sugar, flavorings, syrups, paperboard containers, glass, metal and plastic packaging.

Over recent years, herbal tea companies have invested more in research and development to adapt to ever-changing consumer preferences, forcing companies to hire food scientists, which pushes up wage costs. Despite technological advancements, harvesting and processing tea leaves still requires hands-on work, especially for smaller, family-owned tea estates. These smaller producers often lack the resources for mechanized production.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Herbal tea producers are leaning toward automation to expand efficiency and reduce operating costs. These trends are starting to reverse as more producers invest in research and development and the industry expansively relies on human capital. The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Many Factors Impact World Herbal Tea Prices
volatility_points.volatility_description: The world price of herbal tea fluctuates based on climatic and environmental conditions, impacting the supply of tea leaves and other inputs. Political conflicts and policies also impact input prices, as producers import most tea leaves from other countries. Tea prices fluctuate based on exchange rates because of the supply chain's global nature. A strong US dollar makes imports more affordable, lowering the tea cost.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Changes in Consumer Behavior Impact Sales
volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand from supermarkets and grocery stores impacts tea consumption, as these stores are a large downstream market for tea producers. Consumer preferences and lifestyle trends influence tea sales. As consumers become more health conscious, demand for tea surges because of its multiple health benefits. Consumers purchase more tea when disposable income swells, as many people don't consider it necessary. Expanding interest in complementary and alternative medicine has helped stabilize herbal tea sales because herbal teas are commonly used to improve digestion, respiratory health and sleep.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: CHAMOMILE TEA IS THE MOST POPULAR HERBAL TEA
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Chamomile tea is produced from a flowering plant that resembles a daisy. The tea is used for various medicinal purposes, most commonly to help with relaxation and sleep disorders. This product segment has surged through the end of 2024 as consumers turned to healthier alternatives to sleep aids with unknown detrimental long-term effects. Chamomile tea, with its soothing properties and various health benefits, is projected to dominate the herbal tea market through the end of 2029.

Known for its strong aroma and refreshing taste, mint possesses potent antibacterial and antiviral properties, making it a popular drink for alleviating symptoms and aiding recovery from colds and other respiratory issues.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by boosting imports?
FAQs.answer: An import expansion typically boosts competition and negatively impacts herbal tea production revenue.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Theoretically, as the US economy prospers, consumers should be wiling and able to purchase more goods or more premium items, which should positively impact the Herbal Tea Production industry.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Larger herbal tea producers are investing in research and development to create new unique flavors that will give their company a competitive advantage over competitors.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in areas with well-established infrastructure?
FAQs.answer: Larger herbal tea producers like Unilever have engaged in acquisition activity in order to diversify their herbal tea product offering to include more organic and fair trade products.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to safeguard your company's proprietary information?
FAQs.answer: As many herbal tea producers develop new flavors, there aren't many ways to prevent their competitors from developing similar variations.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to minimize wage costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: Larger herbal tea producers have been incorporating automation into the production process to minimize their dependence on labor.

FAQs.question: How have international tariffs impacted your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Certain types of herbal tea incur a tariff of 4.8%, which has helped protect herbal tea producers from foreign competition.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability?
FAQs.answer: There typically haven't been many new regulations set into place. Thus, regulation has not impacted profit.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover rate compare to your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Inventory turnover is usually higher for inexpensive products than premium products. Regardless, herbal tea typically has a long shelf life, thus, slower turnover doesn't typically negatively impact profit.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Larger herbal tea producers typically benefit from higher profit than smaller competitors within the same industry.

FAQs.question: Do you have secure contracts with trustworthy suppliers? How can you strengthen these financial relationships?
FAQs.answer: Having reliable contracts in place with suppliers of herbs, fruits, spices and other raw materials pushes down the threat of supply volatility. Guaranteed supplies at stable prices can minimize supply costs and aid production planning.

FAQs.question: Are you able to leverage economies of scale? How much would you have to grow to effectively use new scale economies?
FAQs.answer: The scale of an herbal tea producer's operations largely determines its marginal costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company work to develop new products? Do you test the market to determine trends in consumer demand for flavors?
FAQs.answer: Product differentiation and new development are some of the most important factors in gaining market share.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in the healthy eating index? Does your branding focus on health benefits, premium ingredients or other aspects?
FAQs.answer: When people are more health-conscious, they tend to consume more tea, which is perceived as a healthy alternative to sugary drinks.

FAQs.question: How much is your business impacted by import competition? How can you differentiate your products from these foreign competitors?
FAQs.answer: A weaker US dollar benefits herbal tea producers because imports are then relatively more expensive, and the relative price of herbal tea product exports drops abroad.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of boosting disposable income levels? What premium blends do you offer?
FAQs.answer: As consumers have extra money to spend, tea producers can charge higher prices for premium teas and, therefore, boost revenue and profit.
